bibl.title: Letter from George E. Armstrong to Philip Showalter Hench, August 22, 1952

div1.p: Armstrong suggests that Streit, Commanding General of the Walter Reed Army Medical Center and the Walter Reed Army Hospital, would be the ideal choice to represent the U.S. government at the Camp Lazear dedication ceremonies. He praises Hench's unremitting interest and zeal.

div1.head: Letter from George E. Armstrong to Philip Showalter Hench, August 22, 1952
div1.opener:
DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE
DEPARTMENT OF THE ARMY
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL
WASHINGTON 25, D. C.
22 August 1952
IN REPLY REFER TO
MEDDA 619.3 (Camp Lazear) C
Philip S. Hench, M. D.
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I have received your letter of 12 August 1952 concerning the
proposed dedication of certain memorials on the site of Old Camp
Lazear in Cuba. You specifically requested my suggestion as to
who might most appropriately represent the United States Government
at these ceremonies. It would seem to me that Major General Paul H.
Streit, Commanding General of the Walter Reed Army Medical Center
and the Walter Reed Army Hospital, would be an ideal choice.

I have considered the names of individuals closely related to
Walter Reed as possible additional representatives. However, I feel
that in view of their age and present physical condition that they
would not be able to serve in such capacity.

Your unremitting interest and zeal in the historical problems
surrounding discovery of the means of transmission of yellow fever
in Cuba at the turn of the century have been of inestimable value
to World medical science as well as that of the western hemisphere.
The decision by the Cuban Government to memorialize this work is
deserving of the highest praise.

closer.signed:
GEORGE E. ARMSTRONG
Major General
The Surgeon General
